On Wed, 02 Jun 2004 23:50:06 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> Guys one thing worth clarifying is that expressed DNA that does not
> change the phenotype is not the same as useless appendages hanging
> around.  

If the genes are expressed, but they're not changing the phenotype,
then what are they doing?  Do you mean they don't change the behavior
of the phenotype?

> Try inserting a few extra neurons in the
> middle of your brain and see whether is doesn't screw you up. 

Actually, it would probably depend on where you added them, but from
my understanding adding a few neurons at random in an average human
brain wouldn't have much of an effect at all.  We lose something like
an average of 200,000 neurons on a daily basis (out of tens of
billions).  I think it's reasonable to assume that adding three or
four wouldn't make much of a difference.

I think the addition of neurons in the ANNs we're dealing with has a
much greater impact, since our network sizes are in the dozens of
neurons and connections.

> I think it's an accomplishment to add structure that doesn't have a
> deleterious effect.  

I'm not so sure it is.  If enough of this neutral structure builds up
over time, and a very small percentage of it is ever coopted for
adaptive purposes, then it's an efficiency to both your search and to
your network activation.

If at some point a significant amount of that neutral structure is
exploited by the network, then it might be worth it, but again, I'm
highly skeptical of this.  I think it makes much more sense to try to
only keep around mutations that show an immediate payoff for fitness,
even if it is slight.

> Mathematically, it enters the solution into
> a part of new higher-dimensional space which can now be explored
> safely since it is starting at a robust point, i.e. a point where
> the extra dimensions have been optimized not to interfere with
> normal functionality.  

But as you point out, you are now in a higher-dimensional space, and
unless the benefits of adding more time and energy to the search
outweigh the cost, you're wasting valuable resources.

Derek
